ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course hammers home the power of printed mediums to manipulate public opinion. Its surprising to see how innocuous stories can contain hidden agendas and can unconsciously influence you. This course uses 17th-century French printed works to demonstrate how arguments can be made more convincing using elements outside of the logic itself.

The following is a list of terms that generally summarize what I learned in this class, even though it in no way does justice to all that I learned. I think one thing that was really helpful was the practical knowledge that I walked away with which is being well versed in strategies to analyze modern day news.
I learned how to critically view media and better understand what measures are used to manipulate audiences/ influence them in a way the author wants to.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Fun 17th century French works to read. The prof is really engaging and the passion rubs off on the class. Theres also deep questions about the need to interrogate the presentation of our current media and how they unconsciously influence us. The readings are usually pretty short, but there are reading responses up to twice a week (not always) which is a lot of work added up. The papers are also deceptively long due to the 1.5 spacing he demands. The Beinecke visits and the guest speakers he arranged were fantastic, but this course might need handouts from time to time to remind students of key points.
I think that the reading responses were very helpful in order to help the students organize their thoughts so that the discussions during class could be even more deep and insightful.

Strengths: Great instructor, very responsive, interesting theme
Improvement: A little less reading would have been great

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes for anyone interested in the public sphere, media and opinion manipulation/propaganda, and people who are interested in 17th century France in general. People curious about newspapers today and their affects on Society should also consider this class. Anyone who wants to write to a large audience with the intent to persuade should also take a stab at this.

One hundred percent yes. The content was always interesting (it was really cool getting to read literature straight from the 17th century) and easy to interact with, Professor Schuwey is absolutely amazing when it comes to leading discussions, and I found my mind to be blown every day by the conclusions from our classes.
Yes! It was a great class where I learned a lot and the professor was fantastic.

extras.title: FREN 391 01 - Fake News and True Stories
